title-group.article-title: Development of a three-dimensional road texture measurement method as a first step towards tyre road contact simulation

contrib-group.aff: Institute of Vehicle System Technology, Karlsruhe Institute of Technology, Karlsruhe, Germany

author-notes.corresp: S Grollius, Institute of Vehicle System Technology, Karlsruhe Institute of Technology, Rintheimer Querallee 2, 76131 Karlsruhe, Germany. Email: stefanie.grollius@kit.edu

abstract.p: When analysing tyre vibration excitation and the energy transmission of tyre vibration into vehicle passenger compartments, a three-dimensional road texture profile of the surface course is of special interest. Tyre analyses are performed inside an inner drum test-bench at the Institute of Vehicle System Technology. This paper describes the development of a three-dimensional road texture measurement method in the test-bench. Measured data was converted to the distance domain and interpolated to fit a regular grid, resulting in a resolution of lower than 0.1 mm in the driving direction. Power spectra, Abbott–Firestone curve and the shape factor were determined for the measured road tracks. Analysis of the measured road texture profiles of two concrete road tracks showed that the spectral density of the almost unused drum tracks without potholes has to be approximated by two linear functions, depending on the wavelength ranges. Both textures turned out to have a convex shape but differing maximum texture depth. Convex-shaped textures are usually expected to result in stronger vibration excitations. In order to demonstrate the surface courses’ capacity for tyre vibration excitation, a passenger car tyre was driven on each track. It could be shown that both textures are appropriate for the analysis of tyre vibration characteristics.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The Institute of Vehicle System Technology is currently investigating the sound emission and vibration of tyres and chassis on rough roads.1 For the intended analysis knowledge of the three-dimensional road texture is essential. For various road tracks the influence of the three-dimensional texture on sound emission and vibration of tyres can be analysed. Tyre measurements under constant and reproducible conditions are performed on the Institute’s inner drum test-bench, which can be equipped with exchangeable cartridges containing various concrete and asphalt road tracks. Figure 1 shows a schematic view of the test-bench. Table 2 contains the main technical data of the test-bench. It is important to know the characteristics of test-bench road surfaces, as tyre testing on test-benches is often performed by industry and research under constant, reproducible conditions. Comparison to testing on real roads is only valid, if the differences between the methods are well understood. After three-dimensional road texture measurement, an important benefit in performing investigations on tyre sound emission on test bench road surfaces is that the tyre is running on exactly the same, properly-known road track for every measurement performed.

caption.p: Schematic view of inner drum with measurement set-up included.

sec.p: As stated in Gimmler et al.,2 vehicle ride comfort optimisation requires detailed information about road surface characteristics, which is achieved through surface course texture measurement. The road texture corresponds to the deviation from a planar surface. According to ISO 13473-1,3 road texture can be divided into microtexture (wavelength from 0 mm to 0.5 mm), macrotexture (wavelength from 0.5 mm to 50 mm), megatexture (wavelength from 50 mm to 500 mm), and unevenness (wavelength from 500 mm to 50,000 mm). Among these, macro- and megatexture are the most important textures when looking at tyre excitation. In order to analyse the tyre comfort characteristics, it is essential to know the macro- and megatexture characteristics of roads used in the cartridges. As stated in de Roo et al.,4 a three-dimensional description of the road surface characteristics is important to achieve a realistic description of the tyre excitation. With the knowledge of the three-dimensional road texture characteristics the tyre road contact can be further analysed and improved and physically derived models of the excitation process can be developed.

Some texture measurement systems are commercially available,5 but these cannot be used on an inner drum test-bench. The length of the cartridges is approximately 1.5 m. They are formed as segments of a cylinder (Figure 1). Since the surface course is on the inner side of the cylinder segments, the cartridges are not appropriate for use in commercial table-based laser profilometres,5 for which the geometry of the measured probe should not exceed approximately 100 mm. Furthermore, the measurement method is required to be repeatable to allow for changes in the texture due to excessive durability testing. This paper describes the development of a texture measurement method for a surface course on an inner drum test-bench (Figure 1) and subsequent analysis of the measured data.

sec.title: Literature search
sec.p: Surface textures can be measured by tactile and non-contact methods. Tactile means that a stylus is moved along the surface while its movement perpendicular to the surface is measured. The characteristic of non-contact methods is that during measurement the surface is not touched by a sensor. Optical non-contact methods prevail for measuring surfaces, and especially road textures. These methods are usually faster than tactile methods. Furthermore, measurement data from tactile methods is influenced by the radius of the stylus. To account for the radius, mathematical methods known as morphological filtering need to be applied to the measurement data. Only a few of the various surface texture measurement methods reported in the literature performed on a variety of technical surfaces will be summarised in this section. Recently reported methods, three-dimensional methods and mobile methods, as well as methods using the physical principle described below, will be considered.

Brinkmeier6 describes the texture measurement of two road surfaces on an outer drum test-bench using the phase shift process, which is explained in detail in Przybilla.7 Brinkmeier measured segments of 200 mm length with a spatial resolution of 0.384 mm in the circumferential and axial directions. Due to the segmental measurement, the texture had to be reassembled from several segments to analyse the spectral characteristics. As a consequence, the texture height spectrum shows raised amplitudes for wavelengths corresponding to the segment’s length and its multiples. To illustrate the texture characteristics, Brinkmeier calculated standard deviation, mean amplitude, kurtosis and the skewness.

The light-section method is a measuring procedure to obtain object profiles in one sectional plane. The displacement of a projected laser line onto the surface is detected by an orthogonally positioned camera. Using the displacement from the zero position, it is possible to calculate the surface texture height. In Gimmler et al.,2 the use of a mobile measurement system based on the light-section method is described, whereby a resolution of 1 mm for the vertical direction is achieved. Since the vehicle transporting the measurement system vibrates, the movements of the vehicle must be determined from an inertial platform and the measurement data must be further processed to be adjusted for this movement. Due to changing driving speeds and vehicle vibrations, texture heights are measured for an irregular grid. Thus, conversion of the data into a regular grid is another essential step in data processing. The developed method is referred to as ‘Curved Regular Grid’ (CRG). The resultant spatial resolution is 10 mm.

An improved spatial resolution is achieved by the Federal Road Research Institute8 for a mobile two-dimensional road texture measuring system (TMF measuring system), whereby the resolution is 0.2 mm for the horizontal direction and 0.01 mm in the vertical direction. As for the system reported in Gimmler et al.,2 vibration compensation is essential. The triangulation principle was chosen as the measurement principle. A description of the measurement principle is given in the following section. The measurement can be performed in moving traffic at speeds ranging from 60 to 85 km/h.

Assembling measured data in the driving direction, as for example in Brinkmeier,6 is not acceptable as it may influence the spectral characteristics. Resolutions were defined to be better than 0.2 mm horizontally and better than 1×10−3 mm vertically, which is higher than the resolution provided in the publications described.2,6,8 Due to its better applicability to the inner drum test-bench, low costs, and the previous operating experience,9 triangulation was chosen as measurement principle.

sec.title: Measurement principle
sec.p: Mathematically, triangulation refers to the determination of the coordinates of a point by measuring the angles to it from two points with known coordinates at each end of a fixed baseline. In three-dimensional optical measurement systems, this principle is used to determine the geometry of an object. Figure 2 shows the principle of dual triangulation. Usually, a laser beam is aligned perpendicular to the measured surface. Reflections of the laser beam are detected by digital camera sensors called Position Sensitive Device Elements (PSDE, see Figure 2). The projection centre of the PSDE and the laser beam include a known angle, αB. The distance between the PSDE and the measured object is known and is defined as reference distance sA. When the reflected laser beam is detected onto the PSDE with zero displacement to the projection centre, the texture height above the reference surface is zero. When the PSDE has detected a displacement of the reflected laser beam, the texture height can be calculated via triangular relations. Using two PSDEs (dual triangulation), the laser beam will be detected by two digital camera sensors and the average value of texture height is calculated. Fischlein9 indicates that resolution is increased and reproducibility is improved.

The measurable height differences are determined through the measurement range sB (see Figure 2). The triangulation sensor is able to measure height differences within ± 3 mm with a vertical resolution of 0.6 × 10−3 mm. Technical data pertaining to the sensor is given in Table 1. The diameter of the laser beam and the pixel size of the camera sensor are critical for a good spatial resolution.

sec.title: Experimental set-up and procedure
sec.p: The inner drum test-bench used for measurement of the road texture consists of an inner drum equipped with eight exchangeable cartridges containing the different surface courses (Figure 3).

caption.p: Experimental set-up on the inner drum test-bench.

sec.p: The spacing between the cartridges is achieved by applying a mixture of epoxide resin and sand. Figure 1 shows the schematic view of the test-bench. Table 2 contains the main technical data of the test-bench.

caption.p: Technical data of inner drum test-bench.

sec.p: To prove the performance of the measurement method, two rough surface courses were chosen to be analysed, the first being a washed-out Portland cement concrete surface course with a maximum aggregate size of 16 mm and the second a Portland cement concrete surface course with a maximum aggregate size of 11 mm.

The test-bench drum is driven by an electric motor with a driving power of 310 kW (Table 2). Circumferential speed up to 200 km/h can be achieved depending on the installed road tracks. During the measurement of one profile trace, the drum rotates at the lowest possible drum speed to achieve a high resolution of the measurement. The speed is measured via a rotary encoder to calculate the texture data in the distance domain. In this way, a two-dimensional road texture profile can be measured for the entire drum with a sampling rate of 10 kHz. A photo-electric sensor is used to define a geometric starting point on the drum’s circumference. In order to move in the lateral direction above the surface course, the sensor is mounted on a computer numerically-controlled (CNC) axis. The set-up of the CNC axis and the sensor inside the drum is shown in Figure 3. The CNC axis is mounted on a rigid steel structure which is decoupled from the drum drive and drum portal in order that the structure is not excited during measurement. The sensor is moved in a 0.1 mm step for the measurement of each trace. The reproducibility of the sensor movement to a certain position, which is given as ± 0.02 mm, is specified by the manufacturer of the CNC axis. This reproducibility determines the accuracy of measurement in the lateral direction.

In order to control the sensor and the CNC axis and to store the measurement data in ASCII format, a measurement tool was implemented in the software Dasy Lab provided by measX®. Each data file consists of a channel for drum speed, two-dimensional road profile trace and the trigger signal. Figure 4 shows the structure of the implemented tool schematically.

caption.p: Structure of measurement tool including sensors and sensor control.

sec.p: Further data evaluation was performed using the software MATLAB developed by Mathworks Inc.®.

The time delay of the trigger signal of the photo-electric sensor is less than 0.002 s. The calculated average drum speed is 2.77 km/h. The disturbance input is determined by the standard deviation of drum speed, the time delay of the photo-electric sensor and the vertical resolution of the texture sensor. When considering disturbance input, the resolution in the driving direction is calculated as 0.07 mm, with a maximum deviation of 8%. Taking into account the actual and not the average drum speed, the data evaluation described in the next section contributes to further reducing deviation.

sec.title: Measurement data evaluation
sec.p: In MATLAB, each measured two-dimensional road texture data package is loaded into the workspace. The time signal is transformed into a displacement signal using the actual drum speed signal. Since the drum speed is not constant, the displacement data is not equidistant in the distance domain. To obtain equidistant data, the two-dimensional road data signal is linearly interpolated for a theoretical equidistant displacement data signal. The resolution of the equidistant displacement data signal was chosen to be 0.1 mm. A moving average filter was used to reduce single outliers due to reflections during measurement. The filter was designed in such a way that it affected only the microtexture.

A trigger in the photo-electric sensor signal is used to convert the two-dimensional road profile traces into the three-dimensional road texture. This procedure is repeated for all measurement files. A surface plot can be displayed by combining multiple two-dimensional road texture profiles in matrix format. As an example, in Figure 5, a profile with the dimension 50 × 50 mm of the 0/16 concrete surface course is plotted. Figure 6 shows the profile of the 0/11 concrete surface course of the same size for comparison. Figures 5 and 6 show that the variations of drum speed could be totally compensated for the three-dimensional road texture measurement.

caption.p: Measured three-dimensional road profile of a 0/16 concrete road texture.
Measured three-dimensional road profile of a 0/11 concrete road texture.

sec.p: After pure visualisation of the measured road tracks, texture profiles can be compared through the spectra of the texture depths which can be calculated with the Fourier transform or the power spectrum. To calculate the Fourier transform, the fast Fourier algorithm is used for discretised measurement data. Brinkmeier6 determined the Fourier spectrum of texture height for single traces of the data matrix of a smooth asphalt surface (Brink2) and a rather rough surface (Brink1). The mean height Fourier spectra of the surface textures in Brinkmeier6 are comparable to the height Fourier spectra calculated for surface courses measured in the presented analysis (Figure 7).

sec.p: Performing tyre measurements on two road surfaces with identical texture amplitude spectra will not necessarily result in the same acoustical behaviour.11 To better compare two surfaces, the phase information of the texture profile can be taken into account. Alternatively, a shape factor, g, was introduced by Beckenbauer and Kuijpers.12 To determine the shape factor, the Abbott–Firestone curve first has to be calculated. The Abbott–Firestone curve, also known as the bearing area curve, is mathematically defined as the cumulative probability density function, Dx, of a surface profile’s height

The bearing area ratio can be plotted at different texture depths, as shown in Figures 10 and 11. The displayed Abbott–Firestone curves have been calculated for a surface area of the length of 1 m and the width of the tyre contact patch.

sec.p: The shape factor, g, can be determined by reading the percentage of contact area at half of the maximum depth, R, which corresponds to a 50% penetration. Concave and convex shapes can clearly be distinguished through g. The shape factors for concave textures range from 60% to 90% and for convex textures from 20% to 60%.12 The difference between them results from the percentage of the elongation of elevations and indentations of the analysed texture. Due to the deeper penetration of convex road textures into the tyre tread within the contact area, a stronger excitation of tyre vibrations is expected. The shape factor, g, and the maximum texture depth, Rmax, are summarised in Table 4.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: On the basis of the developed measurement method for use in an inner drum test-bench, two road textures were measured with a resolution of 0.1 mm. For measured textures, the power spectral densities were calculated and approximated for the first range of wave numbers through a linear equation with an acceptable regression coefficient of Rls2=0.9 for the 0/16 texture and Rls2=0.89 for the 0/11 texture. The calculated values and regression coefficients are summarised in Table 3. These two ranges were chosen due to the rapid decay that both spectra (Figures 8 and 9) show at a wave number of approximately 100/m. In the first range, road unevenness showing wave lengths greater than the length of a tyre’s foot print and wavelengths that are formed by the underlying foundation and by structures of stone–pothole interactions are included.

The parameters of the first-range approximate function,
S
approx , 1
, spectral intensity, S0, and waviness, w, (Table 3) determined for the two textures differ from those reported for real highway road textures.2,10 The waviness serves as a measure for the long-wave to short-wave percentage ratio. Thus, roads with a higher long-wave percentage will result in higher values of w. The waviness of the measured textures is 2–3.5 times lower than for real road textures.2,10 As the Fourier spectra of the 0/16 surface course and the drum track measured6 showed comparable amplitudes (Figure 7), it is expected that the spectral intensity, S0, and the waviness, w, determined for drum test-bench tracks, are in the same range. Lower waviness can be explained by the rigid construction of road cartridges and drum. Apart from the profile of the landscape, long-wave percentages are also developed on real roads through distinctions of underlying foundation and through usage. Due to the measurement principle, curvature of the drum is not measured as long-wave unevenness.

The low spectral intensity, S0, compared to real roads is due to the fact that measured road textures were almost unused at the time of measurement. Furthermore, real road textures are damaged through water accumulating in fatigue fractures of the texture, which expands when freezing. Potholes are developed, where whole portions of road material break away. Textures in the inner drum test-bench can also be watered to perform tyre measurements on wet surfaces. After such a treatment, complete dehydration is always assured. As can be seen in the spectra (Figures 8 and 9), the cartridge spacings do not have much influence on low-frequency spectral intensity. Amplitude of averaged texture depth for the wave number, Ωspo, is lower than the approximate functions amplitude. This is in accordance with the visual inspection of the measured three-dimensional road profile. In the surface plots, one of the two spacings could not even be identified visually. This means that if the spacing is formed accurately and carefully, no extraordinary tyre excitation from the spacing is expected. This could be further proven through tyre measurement. At the chosen speed the spacings would result in an excitation at fspo = 16 Hz (marked in the hub force spectra in Figures 12 and 13). The first peak in the spectra is at 12 Hz, which represents the first order of the rotational frequency of the tyre at this speed. At the frequency fspo the force amplitudes are comparable low and, furthermore, the first tyre natural frequency is expected at approximately 40 Hz.

For comparison, a second approximate function,
S
approx , 2
, for wave numbers ranging from 100 to 500/m was determined with a regression coefficient of Rls2=0.99 for the 0/16 texture and Rls2=0.98 for the 0/11 surface course (Table 3). The wavelengths of this second range are formed by structures of stone interactions and of interactions of stones with holes caused by break-away stones. The values of the waviness, w, for the approximate functions in this range correspond to the values reported for real rough roads.2,10

Approximating the whole range of wave numbers with one approximate function would result in a linear approximate function which overestimates the long wave road unevenness, but microtexture is underestimated (Table 3).

Comparing the two measured road textures, the 0/16 surface course reaches higher values for the spectral intensity (Table 3), and for the maximum depth (Table 4), which is due to the greater maximum aggregate size and to the wash-out process.

For the 0/16 surface course and the 0/11 surface course, the Abbott–Firestone curve was shown in Figures 10 and 11, respectively. Maximum depth of the texture of the 0/16 surface course is 5.5 mm. Maximum depth of the 0/11 surface course is 4 mm. Shape factors, g, of the 0/16 and 0/11 road texture are 47.2% and 46.2%, respectively (Table 4). The shape factor demonstrates the convex shape of the textures. Hence, both textures are expected to strongly excite the tyre vibrations. In Brinkmeier,6 the Abbott–Firestone, curve and shape factor are determined only for the smooth asphalt surface. Hence, the maximum texture depth, which is approximately 2.5 mm, is considerably low.

To prove the texture’s ability to excite tyre vibrations, a passenger car tyre was driven in the inner drum test-bench on both surfaces. Figures 12 and 13 show the vertical and horizontal force spectra at the measuring hub at a driving speed of 85 km/h. It was proved that the 0/16 road texture results in higher excitation levels compared to the 0/11 road texture. Both textures clearly excite tyre resonances; for example, the vertical resonance at approximately 80 Hz and the tyre cavity around 220 Hz, both of which would result in high sound pressure levels inside the passenger compartment. Analysis of the influence of the texture’s spectral characteristics on force spectra is beyond the scope of this publication, as is the influence of the texture, the tyre uniformity, the tread’s enveloping behaviour and the tyre suspension’s mass and stiffness characteristics.

sec.title: Conclusions and perspective
sec.p: A measurement method for use in an inner drum test-bench has been developed, which offers an improved resolution in comparison to other measurement methods reported.2,6,8 The efficiency of the measurement method, together with data evaluation, was shown. The reassembly of measurement data in the tyre driving direction, as for example in Brinkmeier,6 which induces aliasing in the spectral characteristics, has been avoided. As a further advantage, the method prevents vibration compensation, as required in Gimmler et al.,2 through the decoupled sensor set-up. Another clear benefit of the method developed is that it can be used to analyse other road tracks in the test-bench and the influence of the texture on sound emission on one surface course in the future. Moreover, the method enables us to continuously inspect the alteration, abrasion and wear of tracks through excessive use or, for example, rutting, polishing, aggregate plucking and aggregate ravelling. Through this novel measurement method the differences in spectral characteristic between test-bench road tracks and real road surfaces can be demonstrated. For further measurement, the drum speed can be increased and for an increased sampling rate the spatial resolution can be kept constant. As the rotary encoder delivers a time continuous signal, the data acquisition (DAQ) system would be the limiting factor in the actual configuration of the measurement set-up, as it allows sample rates up to 60 kHz. With this sample rate six times faster measurement (drum speed at 16.6 km/h) would be possible, resulting in the same spatial resolution. If the DAQ system is changed, then the laser is limited, with a cut-off frequency of 100 kHz (Table 1). The main drawback of the method is that a compensation of the changing speed of the drum and the reflections of the laser is needed.

It was expected that the 0/16 surface course would result in stronger excitation due to its higher value for Rmax and consequently higher contact pressure in the tyre road contact zone. Through analysis of the vertical and horizontal force spectra for a passenger car tyre driven on the two measured road tracks measured at a measuring hub (Figures 12 and 13), it can be demonstrated that both surface courses are appropriate for analyses of tyre excitation and tyre vibration energy transmission. Comparing both textures, the 0/16 road texture results in higher excitation levels at the measuring hub. Besides being influenced by the road texture, the force spectra are influenced by other parameters at the same time, especially by the system dynamics of the suspension. This will be the subject of further investigations.

From the higher Rmax value combined with the low shape factor, a higher sound pressure emission for the 0/16 road texture in addition to the higher force amplitudes can be expected. An analysis of the sound emission of passenger car tyres in the inner drum test-bench on the presented road tracks is planned.

Furthermore, it is intended to use the measured data to analyse tyre road contact in order to obtain a deeper insight into the process of force transmission and vibration excitation and finally build models of that process. This can be accomplished by measurement of the contact pressure using pressure-sensitive films or special sensors.
